This could be viewed as an unreasonable restraint on trade and potentially unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text:
5.3
Rejection of defective products
The Customer shall inspect all Products promptly upon receipt thereof and may reject any defective Product, provided that the Customer
shall within seven (7) days after receipt of such alleged defective Product, notify the Manufacturer of its rejection and either:
(i)
request to destroy in field for credit of the value of the defective product and the associated shipping costs (with approval), or
(ii)
request a Return Material Authorization (“RMA”) number and within seven (7) days of receipt of the RMA number from the
Manufacturer return such rejected Product to the Manufacturer.
Products not rejected within the foregoing time periods shall be deemed accepted by the Customer.
perturbation.changed_text:
5.3
Rejection of defective products
The Customer shall inspect all Products promptly upon receipt thereof and may reject any defective Product, provided that the Customer shall within two (2) days after receipt of such alleged defective Product, notify the Manufacturer of its rejection and either:
(i)
request to destroy in field for credit of the value of the defective product and the associated shipping costs (with approval), or
(ii)
request a Return Material Authorization (“RMA”) number and within two (2) days of receipt of the RMA number from the
Manufacturer return such rejected Product to the Manufacturer.
Products not rejected within the foregoing time periods shall be deemed accepted by the Customer.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time frame for rejection of defective products to two days is likely to be considered commercially unreasonable, especially given the complexities of international shipping and potential delays in inspection. Most jurisdictions require a reasonable time for inspection. A two-day window is overly restrictive and could be deemed unconscionable, particularly if the products are complex or require specialized testing.  This could violate implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), which would be relevant in a US jurisdiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC).
